title: Dave Whitlock, a Star of the Fly-Fishing World, Dies at 88
description: Dave Whitlock was 8 years old in 1942 and already fishing in the streams near his home in Muskogee, Okla., when he spotted a golden-brown fishing rod and reel in his grandfathers L.L. Bean catalog. It was unlike anything hed ever seen.

title: Your Friday Briefing: Israels New Government
description: Benjamin Netanyahu is Israels prime minister again. He was sworn in yesterday as the countrys new hard-right coalition took control.

title: Unlikely Parallels in a Year of Momentous Deaths
description: When Buckingham Palace announced the death of Queen Elizabeth II on Sept. 8, the news, notwithstanding the worldwide outpouring of grief it set off, did not come as a complete surprise  not to anyone who had been following the reports of her end-of-days decline. She was 96, after all.

title: U.S. Says Chinese Fighter Jet Flew Dangerously Close to American Plane
description: The U.S. military said on Thursday that a Chinese fighter jet flew dangerously close to a U.S. Air Force aircraft that was conducting routine operations over the South China Sea on Dec. 21, nearly causing the planes to collide.

title: Video Shows Chinese Fighter Jet Flying Near U.S. Air Force Plane
description: A Chinese military plane flew within 20 feet of a U.S. Air Force plane that was conducting routine operations over the South China Sea this month, officials said.

title: The Scrambled Egg Technique That Impressed J. Kenji Lpez-Alt
description: The marvelous and difficult thing about eggs is that even the slightest tweaks in how theyre cooked can have a huge impact on their finished texture and flavor.

title: How Bad Is Chinas Covid Outbreak? Its a Scientific Guessing Game.
description: As Covid barrels through China, scientists around the world are searching for clues about an outbreak with sprawling consequences  for the health of hundreds of millions of Chinese people, the global economy and the future of the pandemic.

title: Their Flights Canceled, Southwest Travelers Were Threatened With Arrest
description: It wasnt the canceled flight on Christmas Day that upset Shelley Morrison the most. It was the police officer threatening to arrest her if she didnt leave a secure area of the airport.

title: Justice Dept. Sues AmerisourceBergen Over Role in Opioid Crisis
description: The Justice Department filed a lawsuit on Thursday against AmerisourceBergen, one of the countrys largest pharmaceutical distributors, accusing the company of knowingly distributing opioids that were later resold illegally.

title: Protesters Rally Against New Israeli Government
description: Benjamin Netanyahus government and its manifesto have raised concerns about increased tensions with Palestinians and protections for L.G.B.T.Q. people.

title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: 1. Russia launched what appeared to be one of its biggest strikes to date on Ukraines energy infrastructure.

title: Russian Missile Barrage Staggers Ukraines Air Defenses
description: KYIV, Ukraine  A swarm of drones and a volley of cruise missiles rocked towns and cities across Ukraine on Thursday, the biggest assault in weeks and the latest in a wave of ever more sophisticated aerial duels pitting Russias evolving tactics against Ukraines growing arsenal of air defense weapons.

title: Democrats Outpace Trump in Seating Federal Judges, With 97 Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON  Democrats fell just short of an ambitious goal of confirming 100 new federal judges as time ran out on the 117th Congress, but they are optimistic they can continue to reshape the courts over the final two years of President Bidens term.

title: Whats Gone at Twitter? A Data Center, Janitors, Some Toilet Paper.
description: Elon Musks orders were clear: Close the data center.

title: Vivienne Westwood, 81, Dies; Brought Provocative Punk Style to High Fashion
description: Vivienne Westwood, the designer who defined the look of punk, using rock iconography, royalty, art and religion as recurring motifs in collections that brought a rebellious edge to British style, before going on to a long and influential career as a fashion designer with an activist streak, died on Thursday in the Clapham neighborhood of South London. She was 81.

title: How the Buffalo Blizzard Became So Deadly
description: On Dec. 19, as the Christmas holiday week began, Buffalo appeared ready for another storm. Officials huddled with weather forecasters while they pulled together a small army of emergency responders, along with the plows, backhoes, salt spreaders and ambulances needed to face the onslaught.

title: The Sidney Awards
description: Tis the season to detach yourself from the news cycle and look for the bigger trends and the deeper human stories. And so every year the Sidney Awards, which I created in honor of the late, great philosopher Sidney Hook, are here to help you take that step back. The Sidneys not only celebrate a sample of each years beautifully written long-form journalism; they publicize essays that illuminate some broad issue or say something profound about the human condition. This year we focus on essays from smaller publications.

title: Jan. 6 Transcripts Detail Failures in Surveillance and National Guard Response
description: The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol released on Thursday 19 more transcripts of its interviews, bringing its total number of transcripts published to about 120.

title: Southwest Is Californias Unofficial Airline. The Meltdown Has Residents Anxious.
description: SACRAMENTO  For the past six years, Laura Friedmans workweek has begun with a short commute up to Northern California on Southwest Airlines.

title: 20 Witty and Wise Pieces of Advice for 2023
description: As the year winds down, its a time for both reflection and for looking ahead. Ive been taking stock of the past year and keep coming back to this advice that I got from Terrence Real, a family therapist and author. Intimacy isnt something you have, he told me. Its something you do.

title: Vivienne Westwood, a Lifetime of Looks
description: With a mother who worked in a cotton mill and a father who hailed from a family of shoemakers, it might have seemed destined for Vivienne Westwood to pursue a staid career in fashion. Yet, the indelible mark she would eventually scrawl across the business and the broader culture owed instead to what she termed an in-built perversity, sparked by a seminal 1965 meeting with Malcolm McLaren. Together, the two went on to frame the visual language of punk. And when their partnership ended, Ms. Westwood continued alone in pursuit of what she once told the historian Jon Savage was her tendency to react against anything orthodox, ransacking the history of dress for bondage gear, corsetry (worn as outerwear), dandies finery, buccaneers raw hides, crinolines and clan tartans to push fashion insistently in the direction of her raw and edgy notions of beauty, her eclectic politics and her lifelong determination to kick out the jams and subvert all norms.

title: Pel, a Name That Became Shorthand for Perfection
description: Of all the myriad things Pel did  the thousand-plus goals he scored and the array of records he set and the innumerable, immeasurable moments of wonder he conjured  the one that is the most famous, the most familiar, may also have been the most ordinary, the most mundane.

title: What Can Stranded Travelers Expect From Southwest?
description: For the many passengers whose holiday travel was disrupted by the meltdown at Southwest Airlines, one question now looms large: How  and how much  will they get reimbursed for their troubles?

title: Biden Signs Government Funding Bill, Preventing Shutdown
description: CHRISTIANSTED, V.I.  President Biden signed a $1.7 trillion spending bill into law on Thursday, averting a shutdown and keeping the government funded through September while adding to his legacy of expanding federal programs as president.

title: Ian Tyson, Revered Canadian Folk Singer, Dies at 89
description: Before Canadian musicians like Neil Young, Gordon Lightfoot, Joni Mitchell or Leonard Cohen, there was Ian Tyson.

title: The Great News Quiz of 2022
description: This was quite a year. How well do you remember it?

title: Ohhh
description: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Todays Theme

title: Variety: Acrostic
description: ACROSTIC  You might be seeing this in 2022, but happy New Year! Team Emily Cox/Henry Rathvon wishes solvers well and recommends a little bit of Weird Al as an accompaniment to this acrostic, hopefully not in conjunction with a dose of lonely Tylenol if you get a headache.

title: Myanmars Ousted Leader Gets 33 Years in Prison, a Likely Life Sentence
description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, Myanmars ousted civilian leader, was found guilty of corruption on Friday and sentenced to seven years in prison, almost two years after she was first detained by the military in a coup.

title: Santos, a Suburban House and $11,000 in Campaign Payments for Rent
description: The company was called Cleaner 123, and over the course of four months, it received nearly $11,000 from the campaign of George Santos, the representative-elect from New York who appears to have invented whole swaths of his life story.

title: Reported Sexual Abuse at California Prep School Wont Be Prosecuted
description: A criminal investigation into a private school in Ojai, Calif., facing decades of allegations of sexual misconduct has resulted in no criminal charges being filed after the authorities said that several factors hampered their efforts to hold potential predators accountable.

title: At 16, He Knew They Would Someday Marry. He Was Right.
description: Anand Goyal and Sabrina Zara Pervez met as teenagers, or so they first thought.

title: Day 30: The Loneliness and Joy of a Late-December Birthday
description: Those who were born in late December are often met with well-meaning pity when they tell people their birth date. Isnt it hard, theyre asked, to have your special day get lost in a marathon of major holidays?

title: When Breaking the Rules Has the Best Consequences
description: Ingrid Nickol Retzer, a police officer in Northern Texas, had the rule to never date or marry a fellow officer. But all that changed after she met Amelia Grace Ragsdale.

title: Is Something This Good Even Possible?
description: Two summers ago, in June, I rang in my 27th birthday by getting so drunk in Napa, Calif., that I gave my Uber driver my phone number. A few months later, in September, my college ex-boyfriend told me he was planning to propose to his girlfriend. Having been intentionally single for years, I suddenly felt like I was losing a race I didnt even know I was in.

title: A Trip (Without Arguments) That Sealed the Deal
description: Allison Cai and Kurt William Galbraith were both part of a large friend group that would frequently go out together, though they never really connected.

title: Two Musicians Find the Perfect Harmony On and Offstage
description: There was a time when having three sisters didnt work in Neal Thomas Yakopins favor. For example, when he was in the eighth grade, they collectively enforced a strict one-hour limit on his basement drum practice. It would be, Hey, Neal, time is up, cut that out, he said.

title: Quotation of the Day: The Beautiful Games Illustrious Face, With the Feet to Match
description: I wish he had gone on playing forever. But then, so does everyone else who saw him play, and those football people who never saw him play are the unluckiest people in the world.

title: Corrections: Dec. 30, 2022
description: A picture caption with an obituary on Dec. 12 about the cartoonist and cartoon editor Lee Lorenz referred imprecisely to the photo of him playing cornet. He was taking part in an informal jazz session with some members of the Creole Cookin Jazz Band and some other musicians; he was not playing with his Creole Cookin Jazz Band.

title: 100 Years Since the Birth of the Soviet Union, in Pictures
description: It was supposed to be a voluntary association of peoples with equal rights, one that would guarantee the peaceful coexistence and fraternal cooperation of peoples while serving as a faithful bulwark against world capitalism.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Russia launched what appeared to be one of its biggest strikes to date on Ukraines energy infrastructure, pummeling Kyiv and other cities and towns. Several regions reported power outages. The attacks combined a swarm of drones and a volley of cruise missiles. Authorities were still assessing the damage, though an official in the Kharkiv region said two people had died there.

title: Where You Start and Where You Finish
description: Endpapers  the pages fixed to the insides of a books front and back covers  are an undersung glory of contemporary childrens publishing. What illustrator or designer worthy of the name can resist such a pair of prominent blank pages? Thus a once purely decorative form is now full of wit, surprise, even feeling. Think of endpapers as a picture books title and credits sequences, or maybe, better yet, an amuse-bouche at the start of your meal and a small cookie plate at the finish. Delicious!

title: A Birds (and Bears) Eye View of Migration
description: To perceive the world through anothers eyes is a profound act of empathy; to do so through the eyes of an animal is an even greater feat of research and imagination. The creators of two new picture books succeed splendidly in this endeavor, shaping realistic narratives that take readers into migratory animals lives, where survival depends on highly developed senses, instincts and relationships.

title: When the Times Square Ball Drop Began at Midnight
description: Good morning. Today well find out why the ball in Times Square doesnt fall when it once did. Hint: An all-but-forgotten shift of a few seconds can make the difference.

title: Welcome to Little Kiwi, N.Y.C.
description: When Tyla Stevenson, a 23-year-old from New Zealands rural South Island, applied for a job at an Australian cafe in New York City, the first thing her manager said was, Oh, its great to hear your accent! Its been so long.

title: Europeans, How Is the Energy Crisis Affecting You?
description: Since Russia invaded Ukraine in the early spring, many people in Western Europe have watched their energy bills climb to dizzying, alarming highs. The increases have spilled over into the wider economy, inflating the cost of other essentials like food and transportation. For many, the cost of just eating and keeping warm has become prohibitive, and it has become a very cold, very dark, very expensive winter.

title: Netanyahus New Ministers Have Very Strict Ideas About Who Is a Jew
description: For years, there has been a growing gap between Israelis and American Jews when it comes to Israels policies toward the Palestinians. But today the issue threatening to divide the Jewish people is not about geopolitics or the occupation of the West Bank. Its about Judaism itself: Jewish fundamentalists are now the dominant element in the Israeli governing coalition led by Benjamin Netanyahu. They plan a hostile takeover of Jewish identity.

title: The Monster in My Home Was a Meter, and It Decided Whether I Ate and Slept
description: GLASGOW  I grew up in a string of dilapidated slum rentals, project housing and homeless hostels. I grew up with a monster in most of those homes.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: FRIDAY  Hi busy bees! Welcome to todays Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlens weekly humor column, Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.

title: Sedona Prince Has a Good Feeling About the Next Era
description: The New York Times Sports department is revisiting the subjects of some compelling articles from the last year or so. In March, we covered Sedona Princes video and the way it challenged the disparities between the mens and womens college basketball tournaments. Here is an update.

title: The U.S. Will Need Thousands of Wind Farms. Will Small Towns Go Along?
description: MONTICELLO, Ill.  Depressed property values. Flickering shadows. Falling ice. One by one, a real estate appraiser rattled off what he said were the deleterious effects of wind farms as a crowd in an agricultural community in central Illinois hung on his every word.

title: The Reverse Logistics of Returning Stuff
description: Returns are the messy, rather-not-think-about-it element of retail  part of a larger process known as reverse logistics.

title: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
description: This weeks new paperback releases include Jami Attenbergs memoir, a new translation of plays by Alexander Pushkin and much more.

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Selections from the Weekend section, including a roundup of New Year's Eve events.

title: The 2022 High School Yearbook of American Politics
description: It wasnt exactly a feel-good year. With brutal inflation, the war in Ukraine, periodic pandemic surges, gun massacres and the Supreme Courts ruling that women do not have a right to bodily autonomy, 2022 had its dark spots. Then again, we avoided a presidential impeachment, and no one stormed the Capitol trying to overthrow the government. So that was a step up. Plus, Sarah Palin lost her House race. Twice.

title: What Happened in 2022? A Look at the Year, in Charts.
description: Ten charts to recap the trends and main events of 2022.

title: What a 1985 Novel Can Tell Us About Life in the 2020s: Almost Everything
description: Noah Baumbachs funny and very stylish film adaptation of White Noise is a great invitation to return to the source material, Don DeLillos novel from almost 40 years ago. When I reread it, I was struck by how hilarious it still is, how accurate to its moment (what in an interview DeLillo called the particular skin of the late 20th century) and yet, like all great books, how it also speaks to this moment; the same absurdities and ironies still apply.

title: The Airlines Know They Are Scamming Us
description: My traditionally cheery holiday social media feeds, usually populated by adorable children viciously ripping open presents like tiny animals, were littered instead this week with images of thwarted passengers in never-ending airport lines and real-time updates on the cascading meltdown of Southwest Airlines, which canceled 57 percent of its flights on Thursday alone, leaving passengers stranded all over the country. My family and I missed this chaos because we left Brooklyn for rural Alabama on Dec. 19 via Delta Air Lines, and I am mostly just grateful that we didnt go to Omaha, as we do every other year to visit my husbands family, via Southwest. For many Americans, air travel is the only feasible option to see relatives for the holidays or to take long trips for urgent reasons, like medical treatments and family emergencies, and when its not cost-prohibitive, its often simply miserable.

title: A Bargain on Billionaires Row Still Clocks in at $50 Million
description: The supertall Central Park Tower, the latest addition to Billionaires Row by Extell Development, has seen a lot of sales activity in its first full year of closings, but not without deep discounts. And this continued through the holidays.

title: Shes Building a Little Jewish Magazine on Big Ideas
description: On a nippy morning, Arielle Angel and her fellow editors at Jewish Currents, a small but influential journal of ideas, were walking toward Union Temple, a synagogue in the Prospect Heights neighborhood of Brooklyn, where they were putting finishing touches on their winter issue.

title: A Cop Called Coco, an Actor Named Mani, a Quebecer Exploring Quebec
description: MONTREAL  Just five years ago, Mani Soleymanlou, a Quebec actor of Iranian origin, was playing characters named Ahmed, Hakim and Karim on French-language television shows produced in the province. Today, his roles include Patrick, a banker, in one successful TV series, and a corrupt police officer with the very Qubcois name Robert Coco Bdard, in another.

title: The Year the Long Stock Market Rally Ended
description: Jan. 3, the first day of market trading in 2022, looked like just another day in a stock rally that began when Barack Obama was still president. The S&P 500 hit a record high. Tesla, the company that upturned the auto industry and made many investors rich, rose 13.5 percent and came close to its own all-time peak.

title: An Architect of Bidens Antitrust Push Is Leaving the White House
description: Tim Wu, a central architect of President Bidens push to clip the wings of the nations largest companies, is leaving the White House.

title: Happy Low-Key New Year!
description: Erin Monroe, who lives in upstate New York and works in human services, knows that 2022  our supposed post-pandemic, Roaring Twenties, carefree year  wasnt all it was cracked up to be.

title: In the Pacific, Outcry Over Japans Plan to Release Fukushima Wastewater
description: Every day at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant in Japan, officials flush over a hundred tons of water through its corroded reactors to keep them cool after the calamitous meltdown of 2011. Then the highly radioactive water is pumped into hundreds of white and blue storage tanks that form a mazelike array around the plant.

title: The Complex History Behind a Vienna Philharmonic Tradition
description: If the Vienna Philharmonics annual New Years Concert is a global success, its legacy and reach rest on five pillars: a marvelous orchestra; internationally renowned conductors; a timeless repertoire, by the Strauss family and other composers of the 19th century; a splendid location, the gilded Musikverein; and TV broadcasts watched most recently by some 1.2 million people in 92 countries on five continents.

title: Once an Open Sewer, New York Harbor Now Teems With Life. Thank the Clean Water Act.
description: Fifty years ago, Congress voted to override President Richard Nixons veto of the Clean Water Act. It has proved to be one of the most transformative environmental laws ever enacted.

title: They Were Promised an End to Homelessness. Now They Face Eviction.
description: Dwayne Seifforth spent years struggling with homelessness, including four sleeping on New York City streets and one living in a Bronx shelter with his young daughter. Then in spring 2020, a city caseworker presented Mr. Seifforth with a solution: a vacant apartment he could afford using a special city voucher.

title: These Young Musicians Made an Album. Now Its Nominated for a Grammy.
description: When the Grammy nominations for best orchestral performance were announced last month, several of the usual suspects made the cut. There was the august Berlin Philharmonic, for an album conducted by the composer John Williams, and the Los Angeles Philharmonic under the baton of its maestro, Gustavo Dudamel.

title: The Choreography on the Ground That Puts Meals in the Sky
description: Millions of people got on planes between Christmas and New Years  braving bad weather, armrest hogs and an epic Southwest Airlines meltdown.

title: Have I Been Good or Bad This Year? Heres Some New Math.
description: Here we are at the end of another year, and as humans are wont to do around this time, Ive been reflecting. Have I been a good person? Has my existence been of net benefit to humanity? When my expiration date comes  whether by murder hornet, bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or an encounter with a garbage truck that transforms me suddenly into a crimson mist  I expect that St. Peter, Brahman, or some similarly all-knowing judge will meet me at the gates of pearl or in the limbo between incarnations, report my tally, and tell me where Im headed next.

title: With Only Dozens of Cancellations on Friday, Southwest Steps Closer to Normal
description: After a nightmare week of cancellations that left Southwest Airlines scrambling to repair its reputation, the beleaguered airline appeared to finally return to its normal schedule on Friday.

title: Critics say a new media law signed by Zelensky could restrict press freedom in Ukraine.
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine on Thursday signed into law a bill that expands the governments regulatory power over the news media, a measure that journalist organizations have warned could erode press freedoms in the country.

title: Xi and Putin Meet Again, Two Strongmen in a Weak Moment
description: When Chinas top leader, Xi Jinping, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia declared a no limits partnership 10 months ago, the pair projected an aura of strength in a direct challenge to the United States and the West.

title: One Man Flees Putins Draft: An Update
description: This week, The Daily is revisiting some of our favorite episodes of the year and checking in on what has happened in the time since they first ran.

title: A Continuing Drop in Murders
description: At the start of this year, Americas crime trends looked grim: Murders had spiked at a record speed in 2020 and increased further in 2021.

title: The Daily checks in with a Russian man who fled the draft.
description: Kirill, 24, worked at a nonprofit for homeless people in the Moscow region. He does not support the policies of President Vladimir V. Putin and is vehemently against the invasion of Ukraine. Yet when Mr. Putin announced a military draft in September after suffering setbacks in the war, Kirill was among those called up.

title: A Housing Market Hangover
description: At the beginning of the pandemic, office workers were liberated from their commutes but found themselves stuck at home and hungering for space. Many Americans went on a home buying frenzy, fueled by cheap debt and an insatiable urge to move. The result was a run up on home prices at a pace never seen before in U.S. history.

title: Deal-Making Thrived, Then Hit a Road Bump
description: Heading into 2022, Wall Streets deal-makers thought it would be hard to maintain last years record-breaking pace for mergers and acquisitions. Still, few thought their businesses would fall by too much.

title: Unmotivated Cowboys Beat Unmotivated Titans
description: They called it an N.F.L. game, but was it really?

title: Giancarlo Esposito Plays Other People So He Can Know Himself
description: Giancarlo Esposito is thinking about robbery.

title: Turning Sports Statistics Into Riveting Cinema
description: Toward the end of The History of the Atlanta Falcons (2021), a seven-part, nearly seven-hour documentary, the writer-director Jon Bois describes a surprise 82-yard interception return by the Falcons cornerback Robert Alford, executed with just minutes left in the first half of Super Bowl LI, in 2017, as one of the very most impactful individual plays in all of N.F.L. history.

title: Trump Tax Returns Undermine His Image as a Successful Entrepreneur
description: House Democrats released six years of former President Donald J. Trumps tax records on Friday, offering new insight into his business dealings that further undermined his long-cultivated image as a wildly successful businessman.

title: Thick Mall, a Market for Size L and Up, Fills the Gap
description: CHICAGO  Jovana Savic kept leaving vintage markets empty-handed. At a size 18, she couldnt find clothing that fit. Extended sizes were easy to find on eBay and Depop, but walking into a store and trying on a pair of jeans felt like an impossible task.

title: Ahead of Major Court Case, E.P.A. Revises Clean-Water Protections
description: WASHINGTON  The Biden administration is working to complete a clean water regulation before a Supreme Court ruling that could complicate the governments ability to protect wetlands and other waters.

title: Do You Know Where These Authors (and Their Characters) Have Lived?
description: Can you guess where these five novelists have resided based on their books? Take the quiz!

title: When Pel Took New York by Storm
description: It was August 1967. The Yankees were languishing near the bottom of the standings, their great years behind them. The Mets had not yet become the Miracle Mets. Still, it was hard to imagine then that a soccer player would capture a large measure of New York sports fans  if not the entire United States.

title: Tributes Pour In as Brazil Prepares to Bid Pel Farewell
description: SANTOS, Brazil  A day after Pels death, fans of Brazils greatest soccer star took to the streets to mourn their hero and celebrate the man they called The King of Football.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Good morning. My grandparents had many books, but the ones I liked most as a child were collections of cartoons from The New Yorker, cartoons from the era of Peter Arno, Charles Addams and William Steig. I didnt quite get the jokes at the time, but on the carpet of my grandparents living room, I thrilled to the idea of them, to the way the captions brought the cartoons alive.

title: Creating the Exiled Sea Creature of Avatar: The Way of Water
description: The first fact you must accept about the tulkun, the marine species introduced in Avatar: The Way of Water, is that they arent whales. The director James Cameron is adamant about this.

title: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
description: A remake of the Spanish director Dani de la Torres Retribution, the Korean director Kim Chang-jus Hard Hit is a furious combination of Speed and Phone Booth that manages to swerve in unexpected ways. In it, Lee Sung-gyu (Jo Woo-jin), a successful bank manager and father, receives a mysterious phone call while driving his children to school. The voice on the line tells Lee that a bomb underneath his seat will explode if anyone leaves his car. The only way Lee or his children will live, the caller says, is if Lee deposits more than $4 million into the extortionists account.

title: Attack on Oil Workers in Eastern Syria Kills at Least 10
description: Assailants attacked a convoy of buses transporting oil workers on Friday in an area of eastern Syria where the terrorist group Islamic State has been active, killing at least 10 people, according to state media outlets and groups that monitor the ongoing conflict in the country.

title: The Weekender
description: A bright, infrared future for the Webb telescope. Also in this edition: the Tom Brady of other jobs and Mickey Mouses copyright journey.

title: Andrew Tate Is Charged With Human Trafficking and Rape in Romania
description: Andrew Tate, a former professional kickboxer and online personality who frequently made misogynistic comments to his large following on social media sites, has been remanded into custody for 30 days by a judge in Romania after the police charged him and three others with human trafficking, rape and forming an organized criminal group.

title: The Forces Shaping 2023
description: If the past is prologue, then the tempestuous year that was 2022 should be seen as a guide to what happens to our climate-changed world in the year ahead.

title: Key Takeaways From Trumps Tax Returns
description: Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee have followed through with their vow to make public six years of former President Donald J. Trumps tax returns, giving the American public new insight into his business dealings and drawing threats of retaliation from congressional Republicans.

title: In Battered Ukrainian City, the Latest Battle is Against Winter
description: In winter, during wartime, any number of obstacles can make life difficult for firefighters in Lyman.

title: The Mets Efforts to Increase Ticket Sales for Operas
description: To the Editor:

title: In Miami, a Dinner to Celebrate Creative Sisterhood
description: On a balmy evening earlier this month, the gallerist Nina Johnson hosted a few dozen guests in Shorecrest, a residential neighborhood about nine miles west of South Beach  where Art Basel Miami Beach and Design Miami were then in full swing  for a dinner that was imbued with the verve and creativity of the artist it honored, Rochelle Feinstein.

title: Biden Issues Six Pardons, Most for Minor Drug Offenses
description: WASHINGTON  President Biden on Friday pardoned six people, most of them for minor drug or alcohol offenses, while also calling attention to trauma inflicted by domestic violence.

title: Test Your Knowledge of New York City's Climate and Environment
description: Take our quiz to see how much you know about the New York regions climate footprint and its environmental challenges.

title: This Diet App Sends a Goblin to Eviscerate Your Kitchen
description: Rachel Harrisons feminist horror novels are some of the most original and entertaining out there, and her collection of stories, BAD DOLLS (Berkley, ebook, $2.99), is right up there with her longer works. Filled with women on the cusp of change  a bad breakup, sexual discovery, an extreme diet  they explore the dark side of being female in the 21st century.

title: Criminology Student Is Charged in 4 University of Idaho Killings
description: MOSCOW, Idaho  The police arrested a 28-year-old criminology student on Friday and charged him with murder in the brutal killing of four University of Idaho college students who were found stabbed to death overnight in a home near their campus last month.

title: How the Speakers Election Could Devolve Into Chaos
description: The election of the House speaker on the floor of the chamber is usually a largely ceremonial exercise devoid of surprises.

title: Mastermind of Varsity Blues Scandal, Rick Singer, to Be Sentenced
description: Labeling him the architect and mastermind of a criminal conspiracy that massively corrupted the integrity of the college admissions process, federal prosecutors recommended in court documents filed this week that William Rick Singer, the college admissions consultant at the center of Operation Varsity Blues, serve six years in prison.

title: Peles Breakthrough Gave Soccer a Black Star
description: Pels graceful genius was just one part of what made him unforgettable.

title: Librarians Are Meeting Younger Readers Where They Are: TikTok
description: The pandemic wiped out decades of progress in childrens reading skills. So whats a librarian hoping to engage children and teenagers with books and reading to do?

title: Georgia and Ohio State Know All About No. 4 Seeds Making Title Runs
description: ATLANTA  He does not like to dwell on past games, the good ones or the bad ones, but Georgia Coach Kirby Smart knows the College Football Playoffs agonies better than most. Twice in the last eight years, he has stood on the sideline of a playoff game and watched a fourth-ranked team outlast his.

title: 12 Workouts to Try in 2023
description: If youre looking for a way to get fit, there is no shortage of opinions about clever regimens to try. There are HIIT workouts, barre sessions, boot camps, Peloton influencers and Pilates gurus. But there is one piece of advice that almost every athlete and fitness expert points to as the key to success: Find an activity you like, and do that activity. Thats it.

title: Resetting Your Routine
description: Hello, Five Weeknight Dishes readers! Im filling in for Emily today; shell be back at it next week, like many of us.

title: Days of Wins and Roses: Covering Pels Cosmos
description: The private Pel, the one even his most devoted fans never got to see, liked to sit in the back of the bus.

title: After Competing Without a Hijab, a Top Iranian Chess Player Wont Return Home
description: ALMATY, Kazakhstan  Irans top female chess player will not return home after competing in two world championship tournaments this week while not wearing a head scarf.

title: Artists and Makers Are Doubling Down on Johannesburg
description: Welcome to T Wanderlust, a new travel newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Twice a month, well recommend global destinations and hotels worth visiting. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every other Friday, along with our T List newsletter each Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

title: My Great-Grandfathers Life in the Great Depression
description: This year, on the Vermont side of my family, a box of daily journals came to light after being packed away for about 90 years. They were kept by mothers fathers father, Charles Orson Brewster, who was a successful builder in the southwestern Vermont town of Manchester. One of my cousins found the journals while clearing out a house for sale. He gave me the one for 1929 and 1930.

title: In a Bad Year for Stocks, Tesla Plunged 65%
description: In a down year for stocks, the 65 percent drop in Teslas share price stands out for the scale of wealth vaporized and the unorthodox behavior of its chief executive, Elon Musk.

title: 61-Year-Old Holocaust Monument Designated a National Memorial
description: Buried at the base of the Kol Israel Foundation Holocaust Memorial are the ashes and artifacts of Jews who were killed by the Nazis at three concentration camps. Engraved on the surrounding walls are the names of those who died during the Holocaust and the names of survivors who have died since.

title: They Said They Went to Mali to Keep the Peace. Now Theyre Jailed as Mercenaries.
description: DAKAR, Senegal  A court in the increasingly isolated West African nation of Mali sentenced 46 soldiers from neighboring Ivory Coast to 20 years in jail on Friday, after the military junta that runs Mali accused them of being mercenaries.

title: How to Destroy a Brand, Musk Style
description: True story: When I won the Nobel Prize in 2008, Princeton quickly set up a special event on campus and reserved a parking space for me in front of Robertson Hall. But when I drove up in my 2004 Jetta, the security people frantically tried to wave me away. They clearly didnt find it plausible that a laureate would be driving such a modest car.

title: For Democrats, Spending Package Marked One Final Opportunity
description: WASHINGTON  Democrats began the year with an ambitious to-do list that included providing billions of dollars in pandemic aid, reviving lapsed expanded payments to most families with children and giving Afghan refugees a pathway to citizenship.

title: Ronaldo Signs With a Saudi Team
description: When Pel came to join the New York Cosmos in the 1970s at the end of his career, he became by an order of magnitude the biggest star ever to play in North America. Now, Cristiano Ronaldo could be filling the same role in the Middle East.

title: Her Childs Naked Dance Killed Her Google Account. New Appeals Path Restored It.
description: When Google informed a mother in Colorado that her account had been disabled, it felt as if her house had burned down, she said. In an instant, she lost access to her wedding photos, videos of her son growing up, her emails going back a decade, her tax documents and everything else she had kept in what she thought would be the safest place. She had no idea why.

title: Bridgette Wimberly, Playwright and Librettist, Dies at 68
description: Bridgette A. Wimberly, a playwright whose first staged work, a drama about abortion, was an Off Broadway hit in 2001 with Ruby Dee in the lead role, and who later made a mark in opera, writing the libretto for the widely produced Charlie Parkers Yardbird, died on Dec. 1 at a care center in the Bronx. She was 68.

title: Ukraine Defeats Russian Drone Swarm, as NATO Head Says Kyiv Needs More Arms
description: For the second day in a row, Russia launched an aerial barrage at Ukraine on Friday, but the Ukrainian military said it had intercepted all of the attacks, as the warring nations wage a lethal struggle of shifting offensive and defensive tactics.

title: Cara De Silva, Food Historian Who Preserved Jewish Recipes, Dies at 83
description: Cara De Silva, a journalist and historian of food and culinary culture who in 1996 edited a groundbreaking collection of recipes amassed by prisoners in a Nazi concentration camp, which became a surprise hit, died on Dec. 7 in Manhattan. She was 83.

title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Juan Guaid Is Voted Out as Leader of Venezuelas Opposition
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  The opposition legislature in Venezuela voted on Friday to terminate its interim government, ending the leadership of Juan Guaid, who for years had served as the face of resistance to the countrys authoritarian government.

title: A Soaring N.B.A. Star Brings His Friends Along for the Ride
description: Mark Daigneault thought he had his first day in Hamilton, Ontario, all mapped out: Shai Gilgeous-Alexander, the star guard he coaches on the Oklahoma City Thunder, would make his morning rounds to shoot hoops and lift weights, and Daigneault would ride along.

title: Woman Accuses Steven Tyler of Sexually Assaulting Her in the 1970s
description: Steven Tyler, the frontman of the rock band Aerosmith, has been accused in a lawsuit of sexually abusing a woman in the 1970s when she was a teenager and he was in his mid-20s.

title: Suspect Charged With Murder in Killings of Idaho College Students
description: The police arrested a 28-year-old man in Pennsylvania in connection with the killings of four University of Idaho students.

title: Tony Vaccaro, 100, Dies; Photographed War From a Soldiers Perspective
description: As a high school student in the New York City suburbs, Tony Vaccaro became intrigued by photography. Two months after graduation, when he was inducted into the Army during World War II, he showed a captain the photos he had taken for his yearbook and requested an assignment as a combat photographer with the Signal Corps.

title: A Charity Tied to the Supreme Court Offers Donors Access to the Justices
description: In some years, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. does the honors. In others, it might be Justice Sonia Sotomayor or Justice Clarence Thomas presenting the squared-off hunks of marble affixed with the Supreme Courts gilded seal.

title: Jan. 6 Transcripts Reveal Disagreements That Divided Trump Camp
description: The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol on Friday released more than 40 additional transcripts of its interviews, bringing the total number of transcripts published to more than 160.

title: Albert Reichmann, Patriarch of a Real Estate Empire, Dies at 93
description: Albert Reichmann, the billionaire patriarch of a real estate dynasty that built the World Financial Center, became the largest private owner of commercial property in New York City, and began the transformation of Londons derelict Docklands into the gleaming Canary Wharf cluster of skyscrapers, died on Dec. 17 in Toronto, the familys hometown. He was 93.

title: Mark Meadows Wont Face Voting Fraud Charges in North Carolina
description: Mark Meadows, a former chief of staff in the Trump White House, will not face voter fraud charges after officials determined that he did not fraudulently register to vote and cast a ballot in North Carolina during the 2020 presidential election, the state attorney general said on Friday.

title: Barbara Walters, a First Among TV Newswomen, Is Dead at 93
description: Barbara Walters, who broke barriers for women as the first female co-host of the Today show and the first female anchor of a network evening news program, and who as an interviewer of celebrities became one herself, helping to blur the line between news and entertainment, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 93.

title: Get Frothy
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  This is Billy Brattons third Saturday grid in a row. Its packed with lively debuts, one of this constructors signatures, as well as some confounding misdirections. My solve had a feast-or-famine feel to it: I knew a handful of entries reflexively, but I needed every last one of those letters to be able to deduce a larger handful of terms and trivia that my mental inventory lacked completely. Some of the fill that slowed me down was slangy, enthusiastic and youthful; figuring it out was invigorating and, frankly, gave me a slight boost of optimism for 2023.

title: Corrections: Dec. 31, 2022
description: An article on Friday about the deadly Buffalo blizzard misstated the month in which 10 Black people were killed at the Tops market in Buffalo. It was in May, not March. The story also described incorrectly the Tops market on Buffalos East Side. It is the neighborhoods only major grocery store, but not the only one.

title: Quotation of the Day: Japans Neighbors Balk at Plan to Release Wastewater From Fukushima
description: You feel this deep sorrow. Why were we not good enough to be treated like human beings?

title: Arizona Doctors Cannot Be Prosecuted Under 1864 Abortion Ban, Court Says
description: PHOENIX   Arizona cannot prosecute doctors under an 1864 ban on abortions that would have outlawed the procedure in nearly every circumstance, a state appeals court ruled on Friday.

title: Barbara Walters Is Remembered as a Trailblazer, and a Friend
description: Barbara Walters, who died Friday at 93, was remembered for her tenacious journalism that blazed a trail for women in the industry.

title: The Best of Barbara Walters
description: Over more than six decades in television, Barbara Walters, who died Friday at 93, became best known for her one-on-one interviews. An integral part of whichever news show she was anchoring at a given time  or of her own Barbara Walters Specials  her interview style became one of the best known in broadcast journalism. Walters, sitting at camera right, quite close to her subject, extracted the kinds of juicy revelations that became her trademark, be they from a president or dictator, a movie star or murderer.

title: Day 31: How The Times Started a Beloved Tradition, in 10  9  8
description: I have a confession to make. It took me an embarrassing number of years working at The New York Times, in Times Square, before someone finally helped me realize that the neighborhoods name wasnt a coincidence.

title: All Glory to T.C.U.s Meme Mascot
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  There are any number of reasons that this cute little Texas Christian University football team has elbowed its way into the College Football Playoff, the realm of the behemoths.

title: Putin and Zelensky will give dueling addresses today with no end to fighting in sight.
description: With their troops locked in a bloody stalemate on much of the front line, the leaders of Russia and Ukraine are expected to share their messages for 2023 on Saturday amid strong signs that the war will stretch through the coming year.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: SATURDAY  Hi busy bees! Welcome to todays Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlens weekly humor column, Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.

title: Mikaela Shiffrin Has Moved On From Beijing and Moved Closer to History
description: Ten years ago, Mikaela Shiffrin, a 17-year-old high school student, won her first World Cup ski race. Standing at the bottom of the course in Sweden as her name flashed atop the scoreboard standings, she had an expression of unmitigated disbelief.

title: What TikTok Told Us About the Economy in 2022
description: The unemployment rate has hovered at 3.7 percent for months. But it is the TikTok-famous quiet quitting and live-tweeted resignations that really explained what was going on in Americas job market in 2022, a moment of renewed worker power and remarkable upheaval.

title: The Red Wave Washout: How Skewed Polls Fed a False Election Narrative
description: Senator Patty Murray, a Democrat, had consistently won re-election by healthy margins in her three decades representing Washington State. This year seemed no different: By midsummer, polls showed her cruising to victory over a Republican newcomer, Tiffany Smiley, by as much as 20 percentage points.

title: Benedict XVI, First Modern Pope to Resign, Dies at 95
description: Benedict XVI, the pope emeritus, a quiet scholar of diamond-hard intellect who spent much of his life enforcing church doctrine and defending tradition before shocking the Roman Catholic world by becoming the first pope in six centuries to resign, died on Saturday. He was 95.

title: College Football Bowl Games to Watch This Holiday Weekend
description: From the College Football Playoff to the Sugar, Cotton and Rose Bowls.

title: Readers Sent Us Pandemic Photos in 2020. Heres How Their Lives Look Now.
description: Family reunions, play dates and holidays never looked so good. But for some, isolation and sadness linger.

title: Watch How Arctic Air Blanketed the U.S. Last Week
description: An animation reveals the details of the freezes bone-chilling journey across the nation.

title: Can I Please Use Your Phone?
description: On a muggy July evening, my aunt Shannon and I commenced our decades-old ritual of eating ice cream and people-watching in a New York City park.

title: The Best Runs You Took in 2022
description: A great pleasure of being an international sportswriter is exploring the world through running. I do some museums and historical sites, but I really get to know a place by running all over it.

title: For Kashana Cauley, Doomsday Isnt So Hypothetical
description: Few demographics illustrate the global anxieties of our era better than New Yorkers, who make monumental sacrifices just to hold onto cruddy housing. The perception of scarcity that haunts the American psyche in particular also keeps couples in lousy relationships and employees in mind-numbing jobs. Such desperation can be enough to push even the noblest among us toward choices that would make our better angels weep.

title: The State of the Midnight Kiss
description: The idea behind exchanging a kiss at midnight on New Years Eve is rooted in a simple superstition: The way you ring in the new year will determine how the rest of your year will go.

title: My Neighbors Pot Smoke Bothers Me. What Can I Do?
description: Q: I live on the top floor of a seven-story Manhattan co-op, with windows facing the back of the building. The first-floor rear shareholders have decks outside their apartments. Frequently, the smell of marijuana enters my apartment, either from people using their decks or from people with open windows. The odor is noxious, but I often keep my windows open because the apartment overheats if the windows are closed, no matter what the season. Can the co-op restrict the use of marijuana so the fumes do not reach other apartments?

title: How a Broadway Stage Manager Spends Her Sundays
description: When Rachel Sterner was growing up in Boiling Springs, Penn., she saw a summer stock production of South Pacific at the Playhouse at Allenberry. She was hooked.

title: The Hottest Place to Network Is an Ice Bath
description: The executives at Daring Foods in Los Angeles had a tough summer. The company, which makes plant-based chicken, had grown 250 percent in its second year, and there was enough turnover that it started to feel, as the founder and chief executive, Ross Mackay, said, like an elephant in the room.

title: Insightful Entertainment For Your Party Guests
description: Theresa Fernand works with tarot cards, charms and crystals, or what she calls tools for intuitive information, confirmation and extra validation.

title: Your Memories. Their Cloud.
description: I have many fears as a mother. My kindergarten-age daughter recently learned a game on the school bus called Truth or Force. My youngest refuses to eat almost anything but Kraft Mac and Cheese. Added to the list this year, alongside outside influences and health concerns, is the possibility that my daughters could inadvertently lock me out of my digital life.

title: A New England Town Invaded by Coyotes Calls in the Sharpshooters
description: NAHANT, Mass.  When coyotes approach children playing in the park, as they do with unnerving frequency in this tiny coastal town north of Boston, Kellie Frary springs into action, trying to drive the animals off while another adult quickly gathers Ms. Frarys day care group.

title: Tonight D.J.s Will Party Like Its 2019
description: Since October, Rashad Hayes, a D.J. from Brooklyn who prides himself on spinning, in his words, every genre, has fielded 12 offers to work on New Years Eve in New York City  triple what he was offered in 2019. So he did what any other enterprising artist who is suddenly in demand after surviving two years of Covid slowdowns and cancellations (and willing to work on New Years Eve) might do: He packed three sets in, at three different venues in Manhattan.

title: Recession? What Recession? Pass Me Some Grapes.
description: The show starts in the foyer.

title: Her Escape From Kabul Was Supposed to Be the Hardest Part
description: The New York Times Sports department is revisiting the subjects of some compelling articles from the last year or so. In August, we reported on a soccer player who fled her home in Afghanistan to begin a new life. Here is an update.

title: For Palestinians, a Rush to Claim Martyrs Killed by Israel
description: When Hisham Abu Naise arrived at the morgue to bid farewell to his son Muhammad, hours after he had been killed by Israeli troops, he was in such a state of shock that he didnt notice the black flag of Islamic Jihad draped over his body.

title: Clergymen or Spies? Churches Become Tools of War in Ukraine
description: KYIV, Ukraine  Andriy Pavlenko, an Orthodox church abbot in eastern Ukraine, seemed to be on a selfless spiritual mission. When war came, he remained with his flock and even visited a hospital to pray with wounded soldiers.

title: Victor Hugo Statue Takes a Prominent Place in Frances Debate on Race
description: BESANON, France  The statue of Victor Hugo has loomed outside the city hall of his birthplace, situated on the Esplanade for Human Rights, since 2003, his white beard knotty, his black suit rumpled, his face cast down at his pocket watch.

title: Their Mothers Were Teenagers. They Didnt Want That for Themselves.
description: JENNINGS, Mo.  Brittnee Marsaw was born to a 15-year-old mother in St. Louis and raised by a grandmother who had given birth even younger. Half grown by the time her mother could support her, Ms. Marsaw joined her three states away but never found the bond she sought and calls the teen births of preceding generations the family curse.

title: At 100, the Rose Bowl Has Seen Many Sunsets
description: The modern-day sports stadium is something like an enormous outdoor (or indoor) living room. Roomy seats  even for those who cant afford suites. Gourmet food. High-tech gadgetry. Video screens that are nearly the size of the field itself.

title: Pope Benedicts Life in Pictures
description: A soft-spoken intellectual and scholar, Benedict XVI was the head of the worlds 1.3 billion Roman Catholics for eight years, sandwiched between the charismatic Pope (now Saint) John Paul II (1978-2005), one of the longest papacies in history, and the reformist agenda of Pope Francis, who began serving in 2013.

title: Long before he was pope, the man who became Benedict was a central figure in the church.
description: Benedict XVI helped run the Roman Catholic Church long before his election as pope.

title: His resignation as pope in 2013 shocked the world.
description: ROME  When Benedict XVI resigned in 2013, he was the first pope to do so in six centuries, and the move sent shock waves around the world.

title: Reporting Vignettes From the Past Year in Canada
description: Vjosa Isai, who reports for The Times from Toronto and Ian Austen, a Canada correspondent based in Ottawa, look back on two memorable reporting experiences from the past year.

title: A Bittersweet First Year for Germanys New Chancellor
description: To celebrate his first year in office, Chancellor Olaf Scholz made a playful nod to his traffic light coalition, a nickname that refers to the constituent parties three colors: He passed out chocolates shaped like the Ampelmann, the iconic figure on German pedestrian crossing signals.

title: Your Best Advice of 2022
description: One of my favorite New Years traditions is writing resolutions for other people. Tonight, if youre with a group of friends or loved ones or strangers who are down for one last New Years Eve reindeer game, hand out slips of paper and instruct the assembled to write a resolution for the year. Put the papers in a hat, pass the hat, everyone draws one.

title: What Pope Benedict Taught Me About Faith
description: On Sept. 12, 2006, a newly minted Pope Benedict XVI delivered an address at the University of Regensburg in his native Bavaria  and stirred up a terrible storm.

title: The Jackal, the Fox and Auld Lang Syne
description: Dear readers,

title: From Germans, an Outpouring of Mixed Emotions at Benedict XVIs Death
description: Church bells rang across Germany on Saturday as leaders around the country paid their respects to Benedict XVI  the first German to be pope in nearly a millennium, but whose legacy in his country of birth is contested.

title: For Conservative Catholics in U.S., Pope Benedicts Death Is Loss of a Hero
description: The death of Pope Benedict XVI Saturday sent a broad wave of mourning through the American church. At the University of Notre Dame in Indiana, a single bell tolled for 15 minutes at the Basilica of the Sacred Heart.

title: American conservative Catholics mourn Benedict as an unofficial figurehead.
description: The death of Pope Benedict XVI sent a broad wave of mourning through the American church. But it held special meaning for the conservative wing of American Catholicism: His death represented the loss of their unofficial figurehead, a shadow presence whose influence they followed even after he resigned in 2013 and Pope Francis became the churchs global leader.

title: The Shameful Open Secret Behind Southwests Failure
description: Computers become increasingly capable and powerful by the year and new hardware is often the most visible cue for technological progress. However, even with the shiniest hardware, the software that plays a critical role inside many systems is too often antiquated, and in some cases decades old.

title: A Look Back at This Years Crossword Constructor Debuts
description: As we close out another year, we want to celebrate the last 12 months of incredible puzzles and the talented constructors who created them, many of whom made their Times debuts in 2022. Weve seen growing numbers of people playing games and creating puzzles since the Covid-19 pandemic began in 2020. Around that same time, developments in our Gameplay app and the introduction of a digital submissions portal made solving and submitting puzzles more convenient. As a result, weve been hearing from more contributors than ever. In 2019, fewer than 10 percent of our published crosswords were created by new constructors. In 2020, that figure nearly doubled, and over the last two years debut constructors have made nearly one-quarter of our puzzles.

title: Anthony Fauci Quietly Shocked Us All
description: The first time I met Dr. Anthony Fauci was at the International AIDS Conference in Montreal during the summer of 1989. ACT UP, the AIDS activist group I was a part of, had scared the bejesus out of conference organizers by seizing the stage during the opening session, then made things worse by disrupting various scientific presentations. Many, if not most, AIDS researchers wanted us hauled away and never heard from again. Little did they know that Dr. Fauci, who was leading the response at the National Institutes of Health, had been meeting with members of ACT UP since shortly after our founding two years earlier.

title: Cheer Up! The World Is Better Off Than You Think.
description: Enough with the doom and gloom! Our planet may be in better shape than you think.

title: The Alt-Right Manipulated My Comic. Then A.I. Claimed It.
description: At 19, when I began drafting my webcomic, I had just been flung into adulthood. I felt a little awkward, a little displaced. The glittering veneer of social media, which back then was mostly Facebook, told me that everyone around me had their lives together while I felt like a withering ball of mediocrity. But surely, I believed, I could not be the only one who felt that life was mostly an uphill battle of difficult moments and missed social cues.

title: The Choice of a Medically Assisted Death
description: To the Editor:

title: With Speeches to Ukraine, and the World, Zelensky Shapes Narrative of the War
description: KYIV, Ukraine  The history of most wars is written by the victor after the fact. But Ukraines president, Volodymyr Zelensky, has created his own sequencing: a story line of the war against Russia in real time that is intended to rally his people, and the Western world.

title: Benedict was criticized for his handling of the churchs sex abuse scandal.
description: The clerical sex abuse scandal broke under Pope John Paul II in the years that Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger  who would later become Pope Benedict XVI  headed the Vaticans doctrinal office, which handled the cases of priests accused of abusing children.

title: Remembering a Revered, No-Nonsense Editor of Culture
description: Last spring, I was arranging to have lunch with one of my favorite people, Andrea Stevens. We had been colleagues for 17 years at The New York Times, where I was a theater critic and she was the sort of editor every writer dreams of finding but almost never does.

title: Walter Wolfman Washington, New Orleans Musical Luminary, Dies at 79
description: Walter Wolfman Washington, a New Orleans guitarist and singer who played his mix of funk, blues, soul and jazz in the citys clubs for six decades, died on Dec. 22 in a hospice in New Orleans. He was 79.

title: For Lula and the World, the Tough Job of Saving the Amazon Begins
description: When Luiz Incio Lula da Silva is sworn in as president of Brazil for an unprecedented third term on Sunday, one of his most pressing problems will be an Amazon at a dangerous tipping point.

title: I Edited Mental Illness Out of My College Applications. Im Not Alone.
description: When I applied to college in the 2009-10 school year, I wasnt worried about my grades or extracurriculars. Instead, I agonized over a dilemma thats familiar to more students than ever as the Common Application deadline looms: What should I disclose about my mental health?

title: Biden Set an Ambitious Goal for Nature. Its Time He Went After It.
description: Compared with the United Nations climate change summit in Egypt in November, the U.N. biodiversity conference held in Montreal this month may have seemed distinctly minor league.

title: How Barbara Walters Went From Today Girl to Pioneering Media Star
description: Long before she became the first woman to co-anchor a network newscast and the foremost prime-time interviewer of heads of state and Hollywood stars, Barbara Walters understood the power of television.

title: 71 of Our Favorite Facts of 2022
description: 1. The Star Trek hand gesture for live long and prosper is derived from part of a Hebrew blessing that Leonard Nimoy first glimpsed at an Orthodox Jewish synagogue in Boston as a boy.

title: The Invention of Elise Stefanik
description: Elise Stefanik had had enough.

title: Russias War Could Make It Indias World
description: Seated in the domed, red sandstone government building unveiled by the British Raj less than two decades before India threw off imperial rule, S. Jaishankar, the Indian foreign minister, needs no reminder of how the tides of history sweep away antiquated systems to usher in the new.

title: Without Updated Tools, N.F.L. Is Still Finding Concussions Too Late
description: In September, Miami Dolphins quarterback Tua Tagovailoa was hit in two separate games over five days. He slammed his head on the turf so severely in both instances that they became a flash point for criticism of the N.F.L.s, and the teams, handling of concussions and prompted pro football to amend its policy regarding benching players after head hits.

title: Breaking Out of the #MeToo Movie Formula
description: When I walked into a screening of Women Talking, all I knew about the Sarah Polley film was that it was based on true events  the rapes of more than 100 women and girls in a Bolivian Mennonite community that were revealed in 2009. The premise did not exactly thrill me. I was, frankly, tired of such stories. It felt as if I had spent the last five years watching accounts of sexual violence get spun into tabloid spectacles, stripped for contrarian essay fodder and slowly strangled in the courts. Experiences of harassment and assault had been swallowed by endless debate. This had made me cynical, then bored. I knew what happened when women talked.

title: Katie Couric: What Barbara Walters Made Possible for Women
description: Every female broadcast journalist working today owes a debt of gratitude to the O.G., Barbara Walters, who died Friday at age 93.

title: Jean Franco, 98, Pioneering Scholar of Latin American Literature, Dies
description: Jean Franco, a pioneering literary scholar who did much to shape Latin American studies in the late 1960s and 70s, examining the regions literature through feminist and political perspectives, died on Dec. 15 at her home in Manhattan. She was 98.

title: Extreme Weather in California Causes Flooding and Landslides
description: Heavy rain and snow caused landslides and flooding in Northern California on Saturday, shutting down two major highways as another atmospheric river system pounded the West Coast.

title: Dave Attell Bids a Heartfelt (and Hilarious) Farewell to Carolines
description: How do you honor the death of a comedy club? First, you kill.

title: Extremely Rare Snowy Owl Sighting Transfixes a California Suburb
description: The forbidding frozen wilderness of the high Arctic tundra is the natural home of the snowy owl, a great predator perfectly adapted to hunting its primary food source, lemmings.

title: Year-End Listener Mailbag: Your 2022 Questions, Part 2
description: Each year, oodles of questions pour in from the Popcast faithful, and each year, the pop music staff of The New York Times tackles them with gusto.
